context: In the early 11th century, the Muslim physicist <b5_0>Ibn <a0_0>al-Haytham<b5_0/><a0_0/> (Alhacen or Alhazen) discussed space perception and its epistemological implications in his <a1_0><b6_0>Book of Optics<b6_0/><a1_0/> (1021), he also rejected <a2_0><b7_0>Aristotle<b7_0/>'s<a2_0/> definition of topos (Physics IV) by way of geometric demonstrations and defined place as a mathematical spatial extension. His experimental proof of the intromission model of vision led to changes in the understanding of the visual perception of space, contrary to the previous emission theory of vision supported by Euclid and Ptolemy. In "tying the visual perception of space to <b8_0>prior bodily experience<b8_0/>, <b9_0>Alhacen<b9_0/> unequivocally rejected the intuitiveness of spatial perception and, therefore, the autonomy of vision. <a3_0>Without tangible notions of distance and size for correlation, sight can tell us <a4_0>next to nothing<a4_0/> about such things<a3_0/>."
